for !a possible trade-off of legal highs, considering
bills that would heave a direct impact on students' drug
use. For the first time in a few years, the Assembly,or the
Senate, at least, appears ready to seriously consider
marijuana decriminalization measures. At the same time,
strong sentiment exists to prohibit that other staple -alcohol -- from legal consumption by eighteen to twenty
Year olds. Both issues tend to evoke very emotional
actions, from constituents and representatives alike, and
thus the final Assembly decisions on these matters are
rather unpredictable. The prevailing mood, though,
indicates that something will be done.
For the drinking age, a number of different proposals
have been put forth to change the present system. In
1974, the Assembly lowered the legal age for beer and
\vine to 18, while hard liquor remained at 21. This
in consistency in types of alcohol allowed for
consumption has prompted a number of delegates to push
for a uniform drinking age.
Before July 1, 1974, Hopkins had, of course, no
Rathskellar. The campus did feature regular parties on the
Weekends, with a keg of beer usually in front of the
freshmen dorms or in the Great Hall, available for
everyone's use. Fraternities also had their rush parties and
normal beer bashes, and there was no great difficulty to
Obtain beer or liquor through older students. Obviously a
relaxed situation -- only when one went off-campus to a
bar or liquor store did the carding and subsequent refusal
or service occur.
That scenario may soon reappear, if twenty-seven
senators set the pace for their House colleagues. On
l'ebruary 15, the Senate passed a bill sponsored by
Jerome Connell (D.31st Anne Arunder) that would
gradually raise the drinking age back to 21. The legal age
would move up one year for three successive July 1st.
This plan would create an interesting life for some
eighteen year olds, who would drink for a few months out
0f the year and then would have to wait for their birthday
to come around again. Those unfortunate enough to have
been born on. June 30, 1959 would find themselves with
three precious "legal" drinking days over the next three
Years.
During the Senate debate, the proponents of the
Connell bill pointed out that alcohol has filtered down to
teenagers in junior high and high schools, and the new
grotici of drinkers has been responsible for a marked
i ncrease in traffic accidents. Opponents countered with
basically
the same arguments that lowered the drinking
age three years ago -- that 18 year olds deserve full adult
li,ghts. And Senator Clarence Mitchell termed the bill the
, wino's windfall," as those under 21 would turn to the
1°eal derelict for buying liquor.

As the Senate passed Connell's bill 27-17, the House
prepared for hearings on its own drinking-age legislation.
Four different bills introduced in the House variously
proposed to raise the age to 19, 20, and 21, with some of
them establishing a standard age for all liquor. The House
Judiciary Committee will eventually settle on one of the
bills to send before the full House.
At Hopkins, administrators are watching the progress
of the bills with obvious concern. Unlike the old "21"
days, the University has an expensive, licensed
establishment -- the Rathskellar -- on campus that would
have to be radically changed with the adoption of any
drinking-age bill.
If a bill does pass the Assembly (and Mandel had
promised to sign any reform of the drinking age), the
Rathskellar faces a couple unpleasant alternatives: no beer
or (if the age reverts to 21) no students. Both situations
spell financial trouble- whether a large, deserted bar or a
soda parlor without the huge volume of beer sales. As
Bettye Miller, Business Manager of the Dean of Students
Office said about a 21-age bill passing, "the Rathskellar
would have to be something else. There are people who
get together without drinking beer -- we could still have
the music and other things. How popular it would be
without beer is up to the students. If they don't patronize
it, we'll have to think of something to do to bring them
back again."

By MIKE GIULIANO
Alex Haley, author of The Autobiography of Malcom
X and Roots, spoke on February 28 before a
University of Maryland Baltimore County crowd
estimated at 5,000. Baltimore County Executive Ted
Venetoulis, never one to avoid public exposure, spoke
before Mr. Haley and declared the day "Alex Haley Day
in Baltimore County." Venetoulis cited the search for his
own ethnic roots and the cooperation between Baltimore
County and Baltimore City as the reasons for his
appearance. The crowd was amused, guffawed a bit. If Mr.
Venetoulis doesn't win the governorship it won't be
because he hasn't conducted one of the more intense and
obvious campaigns in Maryland history.
Haley was struck by the size and warmth of his
audience. "It seems unbelievable when one has spent
around twelve year5 lin hibernation writing a book to see
so many people turn out. You have to be moved with this
kind of audience...(The writing of Roots) transcends what
an individual could do. I feel myself to have been a •
conduit through which something has come... My
grandmother would say, 'The Lord might not come when
you expect him to, but he will always be on time,' and
that is how I feel about the book.
"It began when I was a little i boy" in Henning, a little
town about fifty miles north of Memphis. My
grandmother would invite various women members of the
family to come and spend the summer." Each evening,
these old ladies would sort of filter out onto the porch,
where they would sit in rocking. chairs, talking about
people, places, and events, most of which Haley did not
understand. "I didn't know what a Massa or a plantation
was. My first impression was that what they talked about
went way back." The idea that these women, old and
gray, were once as young as the boy, "would blow my
mind.
"The oldest one they talked about was the African,
brought to America, to a Virginia plantation...The fourth
time he escaped he was caught by professional slave
catchers. When these two men cornered the man. they
were able to overcome him and bring him back. He was
given a choice of punishment, either being castrated or
having a foot cut off." He chose the latter.
There was hardly any family continuity among the
slaves on this and similar plantations, because adult slaves
were frequently sold off, their own children did not know
them, and slaves as a group had little sense of a heritage.
The African was an exception. He was assigned to work in
the vegetable garden, hobbled about as best he could,
fathered a child. The African would point out natural
objects- to his child, teach her the names for them in his
native tongue. Like most Africans, he was given an
Anglicized name - Toby. His identity was taken away, but
he rebuffed the name, called himself Kunta Kinte.
"Every single one of those Africans was from some
place where they had spoken a native tongue. They all
learned to speak this strange new tongue in idiom, or
dialect...Kinte began to tell his daughter anecdotes about
himself, a sense of his past, how he had been captured
while chopping wood to make a drum."
The audience, though most of them had already read
the book or watched the television series, remained silent
and attentive as Haley narrated the history of his family
from Kunta Kinte down to his maternal grandmother,
who "pumped that story into me as if it were plasma."

degree and was teaching in Southern colleges. "When the

On the Road:
Bluejay Hoopsters
Bag it again....
By DAVID KRAUS
On February 18, the Blue Jay Basketball team travelled
to Washington College to play an important MAC game.
For an account of that game, see the News-Letter of
February 22.
Three-thirty. Most of the team has gathered in the
Athletic Center lobby. The bus is scheduled to leave in
fifteen minutes, but it hasn't arrived yet.
Mike Phipps, the leading scorer, sits on a bench,
drinking a soda, talking to assistant coach Al Robinson.
Phipps didn't play in the most recent game- he was sickand he still doesn't look good.
Coach Gary Rupert takes out a cigarette and lights it.
He takes a few puffs and then walks into the offices and
picks up a telephone.
Three-forty. We're scheduled to leave in five minutes,
but the bus still hasn't arrived. Rupert walks to the door,
stares outside for a few minutes, then walks out onto the
front steps.
JV coach Marshall Turner walks to the door that
Rupert just walked through, and stares out for a minute.
Outside, Lovallo and Dean Uhler talk on the steps.
Lovallo is wearing an off-white sport coat, brown pants,
and white Adidas track shoes.
On a separate part of the steps, Rupert smokes another
cigarette.
Uhler walks back inside and picks up a copy of the
News-Letter and begins to read it.
.Rupert comes back in. Two of his young sons are
coming on the trip and have been running around the
lobby. One comes up to his father and talks to him; but
the Coach doesn't seem to be listening.
Three fifty-one. The bus arrives. There is a mass exodus
from the lobby.
Most of the team moves toward the back of the bus. By
the time everyone is seated, there are very few places left.
Rupert's sons take the front seat. The coach sits in
back of them next to Brian Goodman, the team manager.
Rupert looks toward the back and sees Raymond Plack
standing up.
"Sit down, Ray" and Plack finds a seat.
Rupert lights up a cigarette.
Bob Babb, the assistant trainer and an assistant coach
of sorts, is sitting across the aisle from me and see me
writing. He reads the last entry and realizes what I'm
doing.
"If you write down each time the Coach smokes a
cigarette," he says, "you'll be writing that all night."
Four-ten. We're still in the city. The bus is very quiet.
Most of the team members are reading.
Many are reading the News-Letter. Dan Kopcza is
reading The Evening Sun. Brian Gapsis, sitting next to me,
is reading a book entitled How to Buy Stocks .
Four-fifteen. Brian Goodman suggests playing the letter
game. There's not that much interest, but he finally
rounds up Rupert, Robinson and Babb to play. I don't
know what it is, so I look over Babb's shoulder.
It's not too difficult. Someone says a phrase, "Johns
Hopkins University" for example, and on a piece of paper
you spell that phrase down the side of the paper, the "J".
on the first line, the "0" on the second line and so on.
Someone then says a second phrase of an equal number of
letters, "the bus goes down the trail," for example, and
you write that on the paper next to the first phrase in a
similar manner.
We play several rounds. Each lasts about fifteen
minutes.
Five o'clock. We start a fourth round. The players have
changed. Babb has fallen asleep and John Finston has now
joined in.
Five-twenty-five. We've stopped playing and the bus is
still very quiet. Rupert is sitting on the front seat and one
of his sons is sleeping on his shoulder.
Al Robinson is in the back of the bus talking to Dean
Uhler and several others.
Brian Gapsis leans forward and asks Marshall Turner
how much farther. Not too far.
Five-forty. Bob Babb and Dave Emala, who have been
asleep,_ are woken by Brian Goodman. They aren't happy.
Five-fifty. We arrive at Washington College. Rupert

smoke 'em,
Jays!

smokes a cigarette. Marshall Turner announces that the
JV game is in half an hour.
Everyone moves toward the locker room. There's a line
in the bathroom.
Six o'clock. A group heads to the sub shop. Where is it?
Up the block.
"I hope around here up the block doesn't mean five
miles," David Nagelsberg adds.
I drop back and walk with Mike Phipps and Duey
Levine. Passing one of the buildings, we hear a scream.
"The natives are restless," I comment.
The talk turns to Washington College and what it's
probably like. It's pretty much out in the middle of
nowhere. Yeah, they probably do nothing but drink. You
could probably make a fortune selling drugs.
We pass a large gassy area in front of a building.
Suddenly, someone in a car roars onto the grass and
proceeds to alternately speed up and gun his brakes in an
attempt to spin out. He is only partially successful.
Mike Phipps doesn't look or sound good. He is
coughing fairly frequently. He says that he had a
temperature of 103 on Tuesday, but now he feels alright.
Six-ten. We get to the sub shop. There's a pizza place
next door and the other group has gone in there. Phipps,
Levine and I decide to get subs and take them back and
eat them at the gym.
It doesn't take too long for the subs to be made and we
begin to walk back. The conversation of the return trip is
of fraternities and rush parties.
Six-thrity. We get back to the gym with our food.
Rupert takes one look at us and tells us to go downstairs

Six-fifty. We finish eating and walk upstairs to watch

The varsity team is spread out through the stands.
Phipps and Levine are sitting at one end. Al Robinson and
Brian Gapsis are talking at the opposite end. Somewhere
in the middle, Dean Uhler, John Finston and Kevin Kabat
are sitting- still in the same place as they were an hour

Six-fifty-five. Halftime for the JV game. Hopkins is
losing 44-35. Coach Rupert's sons spend the halftime on

Seven-ten. Halftime ends. Kabat and Uhler go

Seven-fifteen. Nagelberg and Plack arrive back from

Seven-twenty-five. Rupert is still upstairs. He smokes a
cigarette.
Seven-thirty. The team is in the locker room and all the
players have changed. They are getting ready for the
game.
Andy Scheinfeld is doing stretching exercises. Randy
Lovallo is making sure his thigh is alright. Bob Babb, the

By DAVID KRAUS
On February 18, the Blue Jay Basketball team travelled
to Washington College to play an important MAC game.
For an account of that game, see the News-Letter of
February 22.
Three-thirty. Most of the team has gathered in the
Athletic Center lobby. The bus is scheduled to leave in
fifteen minutes, but it hasn't arrived yet.
Mike Phipps, the leading scorer, sits on a bench,
drinking a soda, talking to assistant coach Al Robinson.
Phipps didn't play in the most recent game- he was sickand he still doesn't look good.
Coach Gary Rupert takes out a cigarette and lights it.
He takes a few puffs and then walks into the offices and
picks up a telephone.
Three-forty. We're scheduled to leave in five minutes,
but the bus still hasn't arrived. Rupert walks to the door,
stares outside for a few minutes, then walks out onto the
front steps.
JV coach Marshall Turner walks to the door that
Rupert just walked through, and stares out for a minute.
Outside, Lovallo and Dean Uhler talk on the steps.
Lovallo is wearing an off-white sport coat, brown pants,
and white Adidas track shoes.
On a separate part of the steps, Rupert smokes another
cigarette.
Uhler walks back inside and picks up a copy of the
News-Letter and begins to read it.
.Rupert comes back in. Two of his young sons are
coming on the trip and have been running around the
lobby. One comes up to his father and talks to him; but
the Coach doesn't seem to be listening.
Three fifty-one. The bus arrives. There is a mass exodus
from the lobby.
Most of the team moves toward the back of the bus. By
the time everyone is seated, there are very few places left.
Rupert's sons take the front seat. The coach sits in
back of them next to Brian Goodman, the team manager.
Rupert looks toward the back and sees Raymond Plack
standing up.
"Sit down, Ray" and Plack finds a seat.
Rupert lights up a cigarette.
Bob Babb, the assistant trainer and an assistant coach
of sorts, is sitting across the aisle from me and see me
writing. He reads the last entry and realizes what I'm
doing.
"If you write down each time the Coach smokes a
cigarette," he says, "you'll be writing that all night."
